mn36:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
mn36:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

mn36:2.1.pli: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṃ sunivattho hoti pattacīvaramādāya vesāliṃ piṇḍāya pavisitukāmo.
mn36:2.1.eng: Now at that time in the morning the Buddha, being properly dressed, took his bowl and robe, wishing to enter Vesālī for alms.

mn36:3.1.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto jaṅghāvihāraṃ anucaṅkamamāno anuvicaramāno yena mahāvanaṃ kūṭāgārasālā tenupasaṅkami.
mn36:3.1.eng: Then as Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was going for a walk he approached the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
mn36:3.1.comm: This discourse appears to be set after the previous. In both suttas, while Saccaka is impressed by the Buddha, he does not go for refuge or indicate that he has been persuaded by his teachings.

mn36:3.2.pli: Addasā kho āyasmā ānando saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ dūratova āgacchantaṃ.
mn36:3.2.eng: Venerable Ānanda saw him coming off in the distance,

mn36:3.4.pli: “ayaṃ, bhante, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto āgacchati bhassappavādako paṇḍitavādo sādhusammato bahujanassa.
mn36:3.4.eng: “Sir, Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, is coming. He’s a controversialist who pretends to be astute and is deemed holy by many people.
mn36:3.4.comm: Bhassappavādaka (“contoversialist”) is unique. | For “pretends to be astute” (paṇḍitavāda) see Monier-Williams under paṇḍitavādin.

mn36:3.5.pli: Eso kho, bhante, avaṇṇakāmo buddhassa, avaṇṇakāmo dhammassa, avaṇṇakāmo saṅghassa.
mn36:3.5.eng: He wants to discredit the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.

mn36:3.6.pli: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā muhuttaṃ nisīdatu anukampaṃ upādāyā”ti.
mn36:3.6.eng: Please, sir, sit for an hour out of sympathy.”

mn36:3.7.eng: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.

mn36:3.8.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi, sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn36:3.8.eng: Then Saccaka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,

mn36:4.1.pli: “Santi, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā kāyabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharanti, no cittabhāvanaṃ.
mn36:4.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing physical endurance, without developing the mind.
mn36:4.1.comm: “Development of physical endurance” is kāyabhāvanā, which is not a normal Buddhist term. It is introduced by Saccaka here and collected in DN 33:1.10.117. The literal meaning is “development of the body”, but I translate in accord with the sense.

mn36:4.2.pli: Phusanti hi te, bho gotama, sārīrikaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ.

mn36:4.3.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bho gotama, sārīrikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭhassa sato ūrukkhambhopi nāma bhavissati, hadayampi nāma phalissati, uṇhampi lohitaṃ mukhato uggamissati, ummādampi pāpuṇissati cittakkhepaṃ.
mn36:4.3.eng: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.

mn36:4.4.pli: Tassa kho etaṃ, bho gotama, kāyanvayaṃ cittaṃ hoti, kāyassa vasena vattati.
mn36:4.4.eng: Their mind was subject to the body, and the body had power over it.

mn36:4.6.eng: Because their mind was not developed.

mn36:4.7.pli: Santi pana, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā cittabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharanti, no kāyabhāvanaṃ.
mn36:4.7.eng: There are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.

mn36:4.8.pli: Phusanti hi te, bho gotama, cetasikaṃ dukkhaṃ vedanaṃ.

mn36:4.9.pli: Bhūtapubbaṃ, bho gotama, cetasikāya dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭhassa sato ūrukkhambhopi nāma bhavissati, hadayampi nāma phalissati, uṇhampi lohitaṃ mukhato uggamissati, ummādampi pāpuṇissati cittakkhepaṃ.
mn36:4.9.eng: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.

mn36:4.10.pli: Tassa kho eso, bho gotama, cittanvayo kāyo hoti, cittassa vasena vattati.
mn36:4.10.eng: Their body was subject to the mind, and the mind had power over it.

mn36:4.12.eng: Because their physical endurance was not developed.
mn36:4.12.comm: Saccaka’s question shows he was aware of the danger of pursuing of extreme practices and the need for balance. It remains the case today that imbalanced and excessive practices lead to physical and mental breakdowns.

mn36:4.13.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, bho gotama, evaṃ hoti:

mn36:4.14.pli: ‘addhā bhoto gotamassa sāvakā cittabhāvanānuyogamanuyuttā viharanti, no kāyabhāvanan’”ti.
mn36:4.14.eng: The worthy Gotama’s disciples must live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.”

mn36:5.1.eng: “But Aggivessana, what have you heard about the development of physical endurance?”

mn36:5.3.pli: nando vaccho, kiso saṅkicco, makkhali gosālo—
mn36:5.3.eng: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.
mn36:5.3.comm: Described as prominent sages of the Ājīvakas at MN 76:53.6 and AN 6.57:7.1. Gosāla was one of the oft-mentioned six ascetic teachers (see below MN 36:48.7), while the other two are unknown outside of these passing mentions. But the phrasing of this passage suggests that they too, like Gosāla, were contemporaries of the Buddha.

mn36:5.4.pli: etehi, bho gotama, acelakā muttācārā hatthāpalekhanā naehibhaddantikā natiṭṭhabhaddantikā na abhihaṭaṃ na uddissakataṃ na nimantanaṃ sādiyanti,
mn36:5.4.eng: They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.

mn36:5.5.pli: te na kumbhimukhā paṭiggaṇhanti na kaḷopimukhā paṭiggaṇhanti na eḷakamantaraṃ na daṇḍamantaraṃ na musalamantaraṃ na dvinnaṃ bhuñjamānānaṃ na gabbhiniyā na pāyamānāya na purisantaragatāya na saṅkittīsu na yattha sā upaṭṭhito hoti na yattha makkhikā saṇḍasaṇḍacārinī, na macchaṃ na maṃsaṃ na suraṃ na merayaṃ na thusodakaṃ pivanti.
mn36:5.5.eng: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a hound waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.

mn36:5.6.pli: Te ekāgārikā vā honti ekālopikā, dvāgārikā vā honti dvālopikā …pe… sattāgārikā vā honti sattālopikā.
mn36:5.6.eng: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.

mn36:5.7.pli: Ekissāpi dattiyā yāpenti, dvīhipi dattīhi yāpenti …pe… sattahipi dattīhi yāpenti.
mn36:5.7.eng: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.

mn36:5.8.pli: Ekāhikampi āhāraṃ āhārenti, dvīhikampi āhāraṃ āhārenti …pe… sattāhikampi āhāraṃ āhārenti. Iti evarūpaṃ addhamāsikampi pariyāyabhattabhojanānuyogamanuyuttā viharantī”ti.
mn36:5.8.eng: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.”
mn36:5.8.comm: The earliest Jain text speaks of Mahāvīra eating “only every sixth meal, or eighth, or tenth, or twelfth” (Ācāraṅgasūtra 1.8.4.7).

mn36:6.1.eng: “But Aggivessana, do they get by on so little?”

mn36:6.3.pli: Appekadā, bho gotama, uḷārāni uḷārāni khādanīyāni khādanti, uḷārāni uḷārāni bhojanāni bhuñjanti, uḷārāni uḷārāni sāyanīyāni sāyanti, uḷārāni uḷārāni pānāni pivanti.
mn36:6.3.eng: Sometimes they eat luxury fresh and cooked foods and drink a variety of luxury beverages.

mn36:6.4.pli: Te imaṃ kāyaṃ balaṃ gāhenti nāma, brūhenti nāma, medenti nāmā”ti.
mn36:6.4.eng: They gather their body’s strength, build it up, and get fat.”

mn36:6.5.pli: “Yaṃ kho te, aggivessana, purimaṃ pahāya pacchā upacinanti, evaṃ imassa kāyassa ācayāpacayo hoti.
mn36:6.5.eng: “What they earlier gave up, they later got back. That is how there is the increase and decrease of this body.

mn36:6.6.pli: Kinti pana te, aggivessana, cittabhāvanā sutā”ti?
mn36:6.6.eng: But Aggivessana, what have you heard about development of the mind?”

mn36:6.7.pli: Cittabhāvanāya kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavatā puṭṭho samāno na sampāyāsi.
mn36:6.7.eng: When Saccaka was questioned by the Buddha about development of the mind, he was stumped.
mn36:6.7.comm: While pre-Buddhist texts describe a contemplative and reflective culture, they do not contain clear instructions for meditation. It seems that the practice of explicitly teaching meditation methods was an innovation of the Buddha.

mn36:7.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā saccakaṃ nigaṇṭhaputtaṃ etadavoca:
mn36:7.1.eng: So the Buddha said to Saccaka,

mn36:7.2.pli: “yāpi kho te esā, aggivessana, purimā kāyabhāvanā bhāsitā sāpi ariyassa vinaye no dhammikā kāyabhāvanā.
mn36:7.2.eng: “The development of physical endurance that you have described is not the legitimate development of physical endurance in the noble one’s training.

mn36:7.3.pli: Kāyabhāvanampi kho tvaṃ, aggivessana, na aññāsi, kuto pana tvaṃ cittabhāvanaṃ jānissasi?
mn36:7.3.eng: And since you don’t even understand the development of physical endurance, how can you possibly understand the development of the mind?

mn36:7.4.pli: Api ca, aggivessana, yathā abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto ca.
mn36:7.4.eng: Still, as to how someone is undeveloped in physical endurance and mind, and how someone is developed in physical endurance and mind,

mn36:7.5.pli: Taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn36:7.5.eng: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn36:7.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato paccassosi.

mn36:8.1.pli: “Kathañca, aggivessana, abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca?
mn36:8.1.eng: “And how is someone undeveloped in physical endurance and mind?

mn36:8.2.pli: Idha, aggivessana, assutavato puthujjanassa uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
mn36:8.2.eng: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has a pleasant feeling.

mn36:8.3.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno sukhasārāgī ca hoti sukhasārāgitañca āpajjati.
mn36:8.3.eng: When they experience a pleasant feeling they become full of lust for it.

mn36:8.5.pli: Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
mn36:8.5.eng: And when it ceases, a painful feeling arises.

mn36:8.6.pli: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno socati kilamati paridevati urattāḷiṃ kandati sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn36:8.6.eng: When they suffer painful feeling, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

mn36:8.7.pli: Tassa kho esā, aggivessana, uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa.
mn36:8.7.eng: Because their physical endurance is undeveloped, pleasant feelings occupy the mind. And because their mind is undeveloped, painful feelings occupy the mind.

mn36:8.8.pli: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṃ ubhatopakkhaṃ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhati abhāvitattā cittassa, evaṃ kho, aggivessana, abhāvitakāyo ca hoti abhāvitacitto ca.
mn36:8.8.eng: Anyone whose mind is occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is undeveloped both in physical endurance and in mind.

mn36:9.1.pli: Kathañca, aggivessana, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto ca?
mn36:9.1.eng: And how is someone developed in physical endurance and mind?

mn36:9.2.pli: Idha, aggivessana, sutavato ariyasāvakassa uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
mn36:9.2.eng: Take a learned noble disciple who has a pleasant feeling.

mn36:9.3.pli: So sukhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na sukhasārāgī ca hoti, na sukhasārāgitañca āpajjati.
mn36:9.3.eng: When they experience a pleasant feeling they don’t become full of lust for it.

mn36:9.5.pli: Sukhāya vedanāya nirodhā uppajjati dukkhā vedanā.
mn36:9.5.eng: And when it ceases, painful feeling arises.

mn36:9.6.pli: So dukkhāya vedanāya phuṭṭho samāno na socati na kilamati na paridevati na urattāḷiṃ kandati na sammohaṃ āpajjati.
mn36:9.6.eng: When they suffer painful feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.

mn36:9.7.pli: Tassa kho esā, aggivessana, uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā cittassa.
mn36:9.7.eng: Because their physical endurance is developed, pleasant feelings don’t occupy the mind. And because their mind is developed, painful feelings don’t occupy the mind.

mn36:9.8.pli: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, evaṃ ubhatopakkhaṃ uppannāpi sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā kāyassa, uppannāpi dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati bhāvitattā cittassa. Evaṃ kho, aggivessana, bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto cā”ti.
mn36:9.8.eng: Anyone whose mind is not occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is developed both in physical endurance and in mind.”

mn36:10.1.eng: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama

mn36:10.2.pli: Bhavañhi gotamo bhāvitakāyo ca hoti bhāvitacitto cā”ti.
mn36:10.2.eng: is developed in physical endurance and in mind.”

mn36:10.3.pli: “Addhā kho te ayaṃ, aggivessana, āsajja upanīya vācā bhāsitā,
mn36:10.3.eng: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Aggivessana.
mn36:10.3.comm: This is a standard response to someone making unwarranted assumptions about personal spiritual development (AN 3.60:18.1, AN 4.35:5.1, MN 127:17.8).

mn36:10.5.pli: Yato kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajito, taṃ vata me uppannā vā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassati, uppannā vā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassatīti netaṃ ṭhānaṃ vijjatī”ti.
mn36:10.5.eng: Ever since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, it has not been possible for any pleasant or painful feeling to occupy my mind.”
mn36:10.5.comm: The Buddha is not speaking about enlightenment, but about his determination to persevere.

mn36:11.1.pli: “Na hi nūna bhoto gotamassa uppajjati tathārūpā sukhā vedanā yathārūpā uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyya; na hi nūna bhoto gotamassa uppajjati tathārūpā dukkhā vedanā yathārūpā uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭheyyā”ti.
mn36:11.1.eng: “Worthy Gotama mustn’t have experienced the kind of pleasant or painful feelings that would occupy the mind.”
mn36:11.1.comm: For the idiom na hi nūna, compare AN 8.86:5.3 and AN 4.67:2.1.

mn36:12.2.pli: Idha me, aggivessana, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddhassa bodhisattasseva sato etadahosi:
mn36:12.2.eng: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:

mn36:12.3.eng: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.

mn36:12.4.pli: Nayidaṃ sukaraṃ agāraṃ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṃ ekantaparisuddhaṃ saṅkhalikhitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carituṃ.
mn36:12.4.eng: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.

mn36:12.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajeyyan’ti.
mn36:12.5.eng: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’

mn36:13.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, aparena samayena daharova samāno, susukāḷakeso bhadrena yobbanena samannāgato paṭhamena vayasā, akāmakānaṃ mātāpitūnaṃ assumukhānaṃ rudantānaṃ, kesamassuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajiṃ.
mn36:13.1.eng: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.

mn36:13.2.pli: So evaṃ pabbajito samāno kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:13.2.eng: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,

mn36:13.3.pli: ‘icchāmahaṃ, āvuso kālāma, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye brahmacariyaṃ caritun’ti.
mn36:13.3.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

mn36:13.4.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aggivessana, āḷāro kālāmo maṃ etadavoca:

mn36:13.6.pli: tādiso ayaṃ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
mn36:13.6.eng: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

mn36:13.7.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇiṃ.

mn36:13.8.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi, ahañceva aññe ca.
mn36:13.8.eng: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

mn36:13.10.pli: ‘na kho āḷāro kālāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ kevalaṃ saddhāmattakena sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedeti,
mn36:13.10.eng: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”

mn36:13.11.pli: addhā āḷāro kālāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ viharatī’ti.
mn36:13.11.eng: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’

mn36:13.12.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, aggivessana, yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:13.12.eng: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,

mn36:13.13.pli: ‘kittāvatā no, āvuso kālāma, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesī’ti?
mn36:13.13.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’

mn36:13.14.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aggivessana, āḷāro kālāmo ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ pavedesi.
mn36:13.14.eng: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.

mn36:13.16.pli: ‘na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi saddhā, mayhampatthi saddhā;
mn36:13.16.eng: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,

mn36:13.17.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi vīriyaṃ, mayhampatthi vīriyaṃ;

mn36:13.18.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi sati, mayhampatthi sati;

mn36:13.19.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi samādhi, mayhampatthi samādhi;

mn36:13.20.pli: na kho āḷārasseva kālāmassa atthi paññā, mayhampatthi paññā;
mn36:13.20.eng: and wisdom; I too have these things.

mn36:13.21.pli: yannūnāhaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ āḷāro kālāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedeti tassa dhammassa sacchikiriyāya padaheyyan’ti.
mn36:13.21.eng: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’

mn36:13.22.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:13.22.eng: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

mn36:14.1.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, aggivessana, yena āḷāro kālāmo tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā āḷāraṃ kālāmaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:14.1.eng: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,

mn36:14.2.pli: ‘ettāvatā no, āvuso kālāma, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti?
mn36:14.2.eng: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’

mn36:14.3.pli: ‘Ettāvatā kho ahaṃ, āvuso, imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemī’ti.

mn36:14.4.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, āvuso, ettāvatā imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī’ti.
mn36:14.4.eng: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

mn36:14.5.eng: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate

mn36:14.6.pli: ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ tādisaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ passāma.
mn36:14.6.eng: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!

mn36:14.7.pli: Iti yāhaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi;
mn36:14.7.eng: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.

mn36:14.8.pli: yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi tamahaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedemi.
mn36:14.8.eng: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.

mn36:14.9.pli: Iti yāhaṃ dhammaṃ jānāmi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi; yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi tamahaṃ dhammaṃ jānāmi.
mn36:14.9.eng: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.

mn36:14.10.pli: Iti yādiso ahaṃ tādiso tuvaṃ, yādiso tuvaṃ tādiso ahaṃ.
mn36:14.10.eng: I am like you and you are like me.

mn36:14.11.pli: Ehi dāni, āvuso, ubhova santā imaṃ gaṇaṃ pariharāmā’ti.
mn36:14.11.eng: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’

mn36:14.12.pli: Iti kho, aggivessana, āḷāro kālāmo ācariyo me samāno attano antevāsiṃ maṃ samānaṃ attanā samasamaṃ ṭhapesi, uḷārāya ca maṃ pūjāya pūjesi.
mn36:14.12.eng: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with high praise.

mn36:14.14.pli: ‘nāyaṃ dhammo nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, yāvadeva ākiñcaññāyatanūpapattiyā’ti.
mn36:14.14.eng: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’

mn36:14.15.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, taṃ dhammaṃ analaṅkaritvā tasmā dhammā nibbijja apakkamiṃ.
mn36:14.15.eng: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

mn36:15.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:15.1.eng: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,

mn36:15.2.eng: ‘Reverend, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’

mn36:15.3.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto maṃ etadavoca:

mn36:15.5.pli: tādiso ayaṃ dhammo yattha viññū puriso nacirasseva sakaṃ ācariyakaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihareyyā’ti.
mn36:15.5.eng: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’

mn36:15.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ pariyāpuṇiṃ.

mn36:15.7.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, tāvatakeneva oṭṭhapahatamattena lapitalāpanamattena ñāṇavādañca vadāmi theravādañca, ‘jānāmi passāmī’ti ca paṭijānāmi, ahañceva aññe ca.
mn36:15.7.eng: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.

mn36:15.9.pli: ‘na kho rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ kevalaṃ saddhāmattakena sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi.
mn36:15.9.eng: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Rāma declared: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”

mn36:15.10.pli: Addhā rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ jānaṃ passaṃ vihāsī’ti.
mn36:15.10.eng: Surely he meditated knowing and seeing this teaching.’

mn36:15.11.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, aggivessana, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:15.11.eng: So I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,

mn36:15.12.pli: ‘kittāvatā no āvuso rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesī’ti?
mn36:15.12.eng: ‘Reverend, to what extent did Rāma say he’d realized this teaching with his own insight?’

mn36:15.13.pli: Evaṃ vutte, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ pavedesi.
mn36:15.13.eng: When I said this, Uddaka son of Rāma declared the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

mn36:15.15.pli: ‘na kho rāmasseva ahosi saddhā, mayhampatthi saddhā;
mn36:15.15.eng: ‘It’s not just Rāma who had faith,

mn36:15.16.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi vīriyaṃ, mayhampatthi vīriyaṃ;

mn36:15.17.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi sati, mayhampatthi sati;

mn36:15.18.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi samādhi, mayhampatthi samādhi;

mn36:15.19.pli: na kho rāmasseva ahosi paññā, mayhampatthi paññā;
mn36:15.19.eng: and wisdom; I too have these things.

mn36:15.20.pli: yannūnāhaṃ yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmīti pavedesi tassa dhammassa sacchikiriyāya padaheyyan’ti.
mn36:15.20.eng: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Rāma said he had realized with his own insight?’

mn36:15.21.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, nacirasseva khippameva taṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:15.21.eng: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.

mn36:15.22.pli: Atha khvāhaṃ, aggivessana, yena udako rāmaputto tenupasaṅkamiṃ; upasaṅkamitvā udakaṃ rāmaputtaṃ etadavocaṃ:
mn36:15.22.eng: So I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,

mn36:15.23.pli: ‘ettāvatā no āvuso rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti?
mn36:15.23.eng: ‘Reverend, had Rāma realized this teaching with his own insight up to this point, and declared having achieved it?’

mn36:15.24.pli: ‘Ettāvatā kho āvuso rāmo imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesī’ti.

mn36:15.25.pli: ‘Ahampi kho, āvuso, ettāvatā imaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharāmī’ti.
mn36:15.25.eng: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’

mn36:15.26.eng: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate

mn36:15.27.pli: ye mayaṃ āyasmantaṃ tādisaṃ sabrahmacāriṃ passāma.
mn36:15.27.eng: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!

mn36:15.28.pli: Iti yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi, taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi; yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharasi, taṃ dhammaṃ rāmo sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja pavedesi.
mn36:15.28.eng: The teaching that Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it, you have realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it. The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it.

mn36:15.29.pli: Iti yaṃ dhammaṃ rāmo abhiññāsi taṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi; yaṃ tvaṃ dhammaṃ jānāsi taṃ dhammaṃ rāmo abhiññāsi.
mn36:15.29.eng: So the teaching that Rāma directly knew, you know, and the teaching you know, Rāma directly knew.

mn36:15.30.pli: Iti yādiso rāmo ahosi tādiso tuvaṃ; yādiso tuvaṃ tādiso rāmo ahosi.
mn36:15.30.eng: Rāma was like you and you are like Rāma.

mn36:15.31.pli: Ehi dāni, āvuso, tuvaṃ imaṃ gaṇaṃ pariharā’ti.
mn36:15.31.eng: Come now, reverend! You should lead this community.’

mn36:15.32.pli: Iti kho, aggivessana, udako rāmaputto sabrahmacārī me samāno ācariyaṭṭhāne ca maṃ ṭhapesi, uḷārāya ca maṃ pūjāya pūjesi.
mn36:15.32.eng: And that is how my spiritual companion Uddaka son of Rāma placed me in the position of a tutor and honored me with high praise.

mn36:15.34.pli: ‘nāyaṃ dhammo nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṃvattati, yāvadeva nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpapattiyā’ti.
mn36:15.34.eng: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’

mn36:15.35.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, taṃ dhammaṃ analaṅkaritvā tasmā dhammā nibbijja apakkamiṃ.
mn36:15.35.eng: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

mn36:16.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, kiṅkusalagavesī anuttaraṃ santivarapadaṃ pariyesamāno magadhesu anupubbena cārikaṃ caramāno yena uruvelā senānigamo tadavasariṃ.
mn36:16.1.eng: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.

mn36:16.2.pli: Tatthaddasaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ bhūmibhāgaṃ, pāsādikañca vanasaṇḍaṃ, nadiñca sandantiṃ setakaṃ supatitthaṃ ramaṇīyaṃ, samantā ca gocaragāmaṃ.
mn36:16.2.eng: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.

mn36:16.4.pli: ‘ramaṇīyo vata bho bhūmibhāgo, pāsādiko ca vanasaṇḍo, nadī ca sandati setakā supatitthā ramaṇīyā, samantā ca gocaragāmo.
mn36:16.4.eng: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.

mn36:16.5.eng: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’

mn36:16.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, tattheva nisīdiṃ
mn36:16.6.eng: So I sat down right there, thinking:

mn36:17.1.pli: Apissumaṃ, aggivessana, tisso upamā paṭibhaṃsu anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:17.1.eng: And then these three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me.
mn36:17.1.comm: Also at MN 85:15.1 and MN 100:14.1. These similes, which illustrate the importance of detachment from sensual pleasures and the uselessness of fervent austerities, would fit better below, after the austerities and before jhāna (MN 36:30.1). A parallel to this passage preserved in a fragmentary Sanskrit manuscript of the Dīrgha Āgama does indeed place these similes there, while other parallels vary the content or position of the similes to a degree.

mn36:17.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ udake nikkhittaṃ.
mn36:17.2.eng: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.

mn36:17.3.eng: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

mn36:17.4.eng: to light a fire and produce heat.

mn36:17.6.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ, udake nikkhittaṃ, uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
mn36:17.6.eng: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in the water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
mn36:17.6.comm: Abhimanthento must be “drilling” rather than “rubbing”, which does not produce fire. See too the simile of the man “drilling” into the head below (MN 36:22.5).

mn36:17.9.pli: “Aduñhi, bho gotama, allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ, tañca pana udake nikkhittaṃ.
mn36:17.9.eng: Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.

mn36:17.10.pli: Yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn36:17.10.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn36:17.11.pli: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi avūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṃ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho, so ca ajjhattaṃ na suppahīno hoti, na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
mn36:17.11.eng: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.

mn36:17.12.pli: No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.

mn36:17.13.pli: Ayaṃ kho maṃ, aggivessana, paṭhamā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:17.13.eng: This was the first example that occurred to me.

mn36:18.1.pli: Aparāpi kho maṃ, aggivessana, dutiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:18.1.eng: Then a second example occurred to me.

mn36:18.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṃ.
mn36:18.2.eng: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.

mn36:18.3.eng: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

mn36:18.4.eng: to light a fire and produce heat.

mn36:18.6.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṃ, uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
mn36:18.6.eng: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

mn36:18.9.pli: “Aduñhi, bho gotama, allaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ sasnehaṃ, kiñcāpi ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṃ.
mn36:18.9.eng: Because it’s still a green, sappy log, despite the fact that it’s lying on dry land far from water.

mn36:18.10.pli: Yāvadeva ca pana so puriso kilamathassa vighātassa bhāgī assā”ti.
mn36:18.10.eng: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”

mn36:18.11.pli: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṃ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho so ca ajjhattaṃ na suppahīno hoti, na suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, abhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
mn36:18.11.eng: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. But they haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.

mn36:18.12.pli: Ayaṃ kho maṃ, aggivessana, dutiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā
mn36:18.12.eng: This was the second example that occurred to me.

mn36:19.1.pli: Aparāpi kho maṃ, aggivessana, tatiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:19.1.eng: Then a third example occurred to me.

mn36:19.2.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, sukkhaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ koḷāpaṃ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṃ.
mn36:19.2.eng: Suppose there was a dried up, withered log, and it was lying on dry land far from the water.

mn36:19.3.eng: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

mn36:19.4.eng: to light a fire and produce heat.

mn36:19.6.pli: api nu so puriso amuṃ sukkhaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ koḷāpaṃ, ārakā udakā thale nikkhittaṃ, uttarāraṇiṃ ādāya abhimanthento aggiṃ abhinibbatteyya, tejo pātukareyyā”ti?
mn36:19.6.eng: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

mn36:19.9.pli: “Aduñhi, bho gotama, sukkhaṃ kaṭṭhaṃ koḷāpaṃ, tañca pana ārakā udakā thale nikkhittan”ti.
mn36:19.9.eng: Because it’s a dried up, withered log, and it’s lying on dry land far from water.”

mn36:19.10.pli: “Evameva kho, aggivessana, ye hi keci samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā kāyena ceva cittena ca kāmehi vūpakaṭṭhā viharanti, yo ca nesaṃ kāmesu kāmacchando kāmasneho kāmamucchā kāmapipāsā kāmapariḷāho, so ca ajjhattaṃ suppahīno hoti suppaṭippassaddho, opakkamikā cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, bhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya. No cepi te bhonto samaṇabrāhmaṇā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, bhabbāva te ñāṇāya dassanāya anuttarāya sambodhāya.
mn36:19.10.eng: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. And they have internally given up and stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are capable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.

mn36:19.11.pli: Ayaṃ kho maṃ, aggivessana, tatiyā upamā paṭibhāsi anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:19.11.eng: This was the third example that occurred to me.

mn36:19.12.pli: Imā kho maṃ, aggivessana, tisso upamā paṭibhaṃsu anacchariyā pubbe assutapubbā.
mn36:19.12.eng: These are the three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, that occurred to me.

mn36:20.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca, cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇheyyaṃ abhinippīḷeyyaṃ abhisantāpeyyan’ti.
mn36:20.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and scorch mind with mind?’
mn36:20.2.comm: This, the most gentle of the austere practices, was occasionally recommended by the Buddha as a last resort (MN 20:7.2).

mn36:20.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca, cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇhāmi abhinippīḷemi abhisantāpemi.

mn36:20.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
mn36:20.4.eng: until sweat ran from my armpits.

mn36:20.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso dubbalataraṃ purisaṃ sīse vā gahetvā khandhe vā gahetvā abhiniggaṇheyya abhinippīḷeyya abhisantāpeyya;
mn36:20.5.eng: It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and crushes them.

mn36:20.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, dantebhi dantamādhāya, jivhāya tāluṃ āhacca, cetasā cittaṃ abhiniggaṇhato abhinippīḷayato abhisantāpayato kacchehi sedā muccanti.
mn36:20.6.eng: In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and crushed mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits.

mn36:20.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:20.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:20.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:20.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:21.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I practice the breathless absorption?’
mn36:21.2.comm: This practice seems like an extreme form of “breath control” (prāṇayāma) which was a prominent feature of later Yoga. While the breath played an extremely important role in pre-Buddhist texts, no corresponding practice is detailed. However, precursors may be seen in passages such as Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 3.7.16, where in response to Uddālaka’s question, Yājnavalkya says, “He who controls the breath within is the self, the inner controller, the immortal” (yaḥ prāṇamantaro yamayati, eṣa ta ātmāntaryāmyamṛtaḥ). Jaiminīya Brāhmaņa 1.42 describes a practice of deliberate asphyxiation to induce a near-death experience. Varuṇa deprived his son Bhṛgu of breath in order to send him on a journey to the “other world”. There Bhṛgu saw men cutting other men to pieces and eating them, and other sights both horrifying and beautiful, all the while wondering if what he saw was real, before his breath was returned to him.

mn36:21.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṃ.
mn36:21.3.eng: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.

mn36:21.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṃ nikkhamantānaṃ adhimatto saddo hoti.
mn36:21.4.eng: But then winds came out my ears making a loud noise,

mn36:21.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma kammāragaggariyā dhamamānāya adhimatto saddo hoti;
mn36:21.5.eng: like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.

mn36:21.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu kaṇṇasotehi vātānaṃ nikkhamantānaṃ adhimatto saddo hoti.

mn36:21.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:21.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:21.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:21.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:22.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’

mn36:22.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṃ.
mn36:22.3.eng: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.

mn36:22.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.
mn36:22.4.eng: But then strong winds ground my head,

mn36:22.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso tiṇhena sikharena muddhani abhimattheyya;
mn36:22.5.eng: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.

mn36:22.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā muddhani ūhananti.

mn36:22.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:22.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:22.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:22.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:23.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’

mn36:23.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṃ.
mn36:23.3.eng: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.

mn36:23.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.
mn36:23.4.eng: But then I got a severe headache,

mn36:23.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, balavā puriso daḷhena varattakkhaṇḍena sīse sīsaveṭhaṃ dadeyya;
mn36:23.5.eng: like a strong man was tightening a strong leather strap around my head.

mn36:23.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā sīse sīsavedanā honti.

mn36:23.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:23.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:23.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:23.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:24.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’

mn36:24.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṃ.
mn36:24.3.eng: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.

mn36:24.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā kucchiṃ parikantanti.
mn36:24.4.eng: But then strong winds carved up my belly,

mn36:24.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā tiṇhena govikantanena kucchiṃ parikanteyya;
mn36:24.5.eng: like a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a sharp meat cleaver.

mn36:24.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimattā vātā kucchiṃ parikantanti.

mn36:24.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:24.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:24.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:24.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:25.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’

mn36:25.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāse uparundhiṃ.
mn36:25.3.eng: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose and ears.

mn36:25.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimatto kāyasmiṃ ḍāho hoti.
mn36:25.4.eng: But then there was a severe burning in my body,

mn36:25.5.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, dve balavanto purisā dubbalataraṃ purisaṃ nānābāhāsu gahetvā aṅgārakāsuyā santāpeyyuṃ samparitāpeyyuṃ;
mn36:25.5.eng: like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.

mn36:25.6.pli: evameva kho me, aggivessana, mukhato ca nāsato ca kaṇṇato ca assāsapassāsesu uparuddhesu adhimatto kāyasmiṃ ḍāho hoti.

mn36:25.7.pli: Āraddhaṃ kho pana me, aggivessana, vīriyaṃ hoti asallīnaṃ upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā. Sāraddho ca pana me kāyo hoti appaṭippassaddho teneva dukkhappadhānena padhānābhitunnassa sato.
mn36:25.7.eng: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

mn36:25.8.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā dukkhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:25.8.eng: But even such painful feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:26.1.pli: Apissu maṃ, aggivessana, devatā disvā evamāhaṃsu:
mn36:26.1.eng: Then some deities saw me and said,

mn36:26.4.pli: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, api ca kālaṃ karotī’ti.

mn36:26.6.pli: ‘na kālaṅkato samaṇo gotamo, napi kālaṃ karoti, arahaṃ samaṇo gotamo, vihāro tveva so arahato evarūpo hotī’ti.
mn36:26.6.eng: ‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’

mn36:27.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’

mn36:27.3.pli: Atha kho maṃ, aggivessana, devatā upasaṅkamitvā etadavocuṃ:
mn36:27.3.eng: But deities came to me and said,

mn36:27.4.pli: ‘mā kho tvaṃ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajji.
mn36:27.4.eng: ‘Good fellow, don’t practice totally cutting off food.

mn36:27.5.pli: Sace kho tvaṃ, mārisa, sabbaso āhārupacchedāya paṭipajjissasi, tassa te mayaṃ dibbaṃ ojaṃ lomakūpehi ajjhohāressāma, tāya tvaṃ yāpessasī’ti.
mn36:27.5.eng: If you do, we’ll infuse heavenly nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’

mn36:27.7.pli: ‘ahañceva kho pana sabbaso ajajjitaṃ paṭijāneyyaṃ, imā ca me devatā dibbaṃ ojaṃ lomakūpehi ajjhohāreyyuṃ, tāya cāhaṃ yāpeyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa musā’ti.
mn36:27.7.eng: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing heavenly nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’

mn36:27.8.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, tā devatā paccācikkhāmi, ‘halan’ti vadāmi.
mn36:27.8.eng: So I refused those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’

mn36:28.2.pli: ‘yannūnāhaṃ thokaṃ thokaṃ āhāraṃ āhāreyyaṃ, pasataṃ pasataṃ, yadi vā muggayūsaṃ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṃ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṃ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsan’ti.
mn36:28.2.eng: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a handful of broth made from mung beans, horse gram, chickpeas, or green gram?’

mn36:28.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, thokaṃ thokaṃ āhāraṃ āhāresiṃ, pasataṃ pasataṃ, yadi vā muggayūsaṃ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṃ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṃ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṃ.

mn36:28.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, thokaṃ thokaṃ āhāraṃ āhārayato, pasataṃ pasataṃ, yadi vā muggayūsaṃ, yadi vā kulatthayūsaṃ, yadi vā kaḷāyayūsaṃ, yadi vā hareṇukayūsaṃ, adhimattakasimānaṃ patto kāyo hoti.
mn36:28.4.eng: until my body became severely emaciated.

mn36:28.5.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma āsītikapabbāni vā kāḷapabbāni vā; evamevassu me aṅgapaccaṅgāni bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.5.eng: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,

mn36:28.6.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma oṭṭhapadaṃ; evamevassu me ānisadaṃ hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.6.eng: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,

mn36:28.7.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma vaṭṭanāvaḷī; evamevassu me piṭṭhikaṇṭako uṇṇatāvanato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.7.eng: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,

mn36:28.8.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma jarasālāya gopānasiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti; evamevassu me phāsuḷiyo oluggaviluggā bhavanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.8.eng: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.

mn36:28.9.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma gambhīre udapāne udakatārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti; evamevassu me akkhikūpesu akkhitārakā gambhīragatā okkhāyikā dissanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.9.eng: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.

mn36:28.10.pli: Seyyathāpi nāma tittakālābu āmakacchinno vātātapena samphuṭito hoti sammilāto; evamevassu me sīsacchavi samphuṭitā hoti sammilātā tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.10.eng: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.

mn36:28.11.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, udaracchaviṃ parimasissāmīti piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ parimasissāmīti udaracchaviṃyeva pariggaṇhāmi, yāvassu me, aggivessana, udaracchavi piṭṭhikaṇṭakaṃ allīnā hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.11.eng: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.

mn36:28.12.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, vaccaṃ vā muttaṃ vā karissāmīti tattheva avakujjo papatāmi tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.12.eng: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.

mn36:28.13.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, imameva kāyaṃ assāsento pāṇinā gattāni anumajjāmi. Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, pāṇinā gattāni anumajjato pūtimūlāni lomāni kāyasmā papatanti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:28.13.eng: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.

mn36:29.1.pli: Apissu maṃ, aggivessana, manussā disvā evamāhaṃsu: ‘kāḷo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
mn36:29.1.eng: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’

mn36:29.2.pli: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṃsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo, sāmo samaṇo gotamo’ti.
mn36:29.2.eng: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’

mn36:29.3.pli: Ekacce manussā evamāhaṃsu: ‘na kāḷo samaṇo gotamo, napi sāmo, maṅguracchavi samaṇo gotamo’ti.
mn36:29.3.eng: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has dingy skin.’
mn36:29.3.comm: His skin was “dingy” (maṅgura, Sanskrit maṅgura or madgura) like the blotchy mud-green of common catfish (clarias magur), which has a dingy greenish or muddy color for camouflage on the riverbed. See also SN 19.14.

mn36:29.4.pli: Yāvassu me, aggivessana, tāva parisuddho chavivaṇṇo pariyodāto upahato hoti tāyevappāhāratāya.
mn36:29.4.eng: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.

mn36:30.2.pli: ‘ye kho keci atītamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayiṃsu, etāvaparamaṃ, nayito bhiyyo.
mn36:30.2.eng: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.

mn36:30.3.pli: Yepi hi keci anāgatamaddhānaṃ samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayissanti, etāvaparamaṃ, nayito bhiyyo.

mn36:30.4.pli: Yepi hi keci etarahi samaṇā vā brāhmaṇā vā opakkamikā dukkhā tibbā kharā kaṭukā vedanā vedayanti, etāvaparamaṃ, nayito bhiyyo.

mn36:30.5.pli: Na kho panāhaṃ imāya kaṭukāya dukkarakārikāya adhigacchāmi uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanavisesaṃ.
mn36:30.5.eng: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.

mn36:30.6.pli: Siyā nu kho añño maggo bodhāyā’ti?
mn36:30.6.eng: Could there be another path to awakening?’

mn36:31.2.pli: ‘abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ pitu sakkassa kammante sītāya jambucchāyāya nisinno vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja viharitā.
mn36:31.2.eng: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of a black plum tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
mn36:31.2.comm: The gentle and pleasant practice of jhāna is contrasted with the fiery austerities. The Bodhisatta had previously developed meditation under his former teachers, which included the practice of jhāna. But there the practice was embedded in theory, since he first memorized scripture, which would have taught him that such states were a revelation of the true self as the cosmic divinity of sheer consciousness. Thus what he rejected was “that teaching”, i.e. the system of philosophy and practice as a whole, which leads only to rebirth in a realm that, for all its sublimity, is still conditioned. Now he recalls entering deep meditation with the innocence of youth, following no system or philosophy. This showed him that peace of mind is a natural process of letting go, not dependent on (Upaniṣadic) metaphysics.

mn36:31.3.pli: Siyā nu kho eso maggo bodhāyā’ti?
mn36:31.3.eng: Could that be the path to awakening?’

mn36:31.4.pli: Tassa mayhaṃ, aggivessana, satānusāri viññāṇaṃ ahosi:
mn36:31.4.eng: Stemming from that memory came the understanding:

mn36:32.2.pli: ‘kiṃ nu kho ahaṃ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, yaṃ taṃ sukhaṃ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti?
mn36:32.2.eng: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’

mn36:32.4.pli: ‘na kho ahaṃ tassa sukhassa bhāyāmi, yaṃ taṃ sukhaṃ aññatreva kāmehi aññatra akusalehi dhammehī’ti.
mn36:32.4.eng: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’

mn36:33.2.pli: ‘na kho taṃ sukaraṃ sukhaṃ adhigantuṃ evaṃ adhimattakasimānaṃ pattakāyena, yannūnāhaṃ oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāreyyaṃ odanakummāsan’ti.
mn36:33.2.eng: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so severely emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’
mn36:33.2.comm: The dependence of the mind on food was proven by Uddālaka when he asked Śvetaketu to go without food for fifteen days, after which he could not recall any of the hymns (Chāndogya Upaniṣad 6.7). | Note how this contrasts with the unhealthy cycle of starving and fattening described above (MN 36:6.5).

mn36:33.3.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāresiṃ odanakummāsaṃ.
mn36:33.3.eng: So I ate some solid food.

mn36:33.4.pli: Tena kho pana maṃ, aggivessana, samayena pañca bhikkhū paccupaṭṭhitā honti:
mn36:33.4.eng: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,

mn36:33.5.pli: ‘yaṃ kho samaṇo gotamo dhammaṃ adhigamissati, taṃ no ārocessatī’ti.
mn36:33.5.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’

mn36:33.6.pli: Yato kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāresiṃ odanakummāsaṃ, atha me te pañca bhikkhū nibbijja pakkamiṃsu:
mn36:33.6.eng: But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying,

mn36:33.7.eng: ‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’

mn36:34.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, oḷārikaṃ āhāraṃ āhāretvā, balaṃ gahetvā, vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṃ savicāraṃ vivekajaṃ pītisukhaṃ paṭhamaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:34.1.eng: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn36:34.2.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:34.2.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:35-37.1.pli: Vitakkavicārānaṃ vūpasamā ajjhattaṃ sampasādanaṃ cetaso ekodibhāvaṃ avitakkaṃ avicāraṃ samādhijaṃ pītisukhaṃ dutiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:35-37.1.eng: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.

mn36:35-37.2.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:35-37.2.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:35-37.3.pli: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca vihāsiṃ, sato ca sampajāno. Sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṃvedesiṃ yaṃ taṃ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:35-37.3.eng: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

mn36:35-37.4.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:35-37.4.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:35-37.5.pli: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṃ atthaṅgamā, adukkhamasukhaṃ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṃ catutthaṃ jhānaṃ upasampajja vihāsiṃ.
mn36:35-37.5.eng: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.

mn36:35-37.6.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:35-37.6.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:38.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
mn36:38.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.

mn36:38.2.pli: So anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi, seyyathidaṃ—ekampi jātiṃ …pe… iti sākāraṃ sauddesaṃ anekavihitaṃ pubbenivāsaṃ anussarāmi.
mn36:38.2.eng: I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.

mn36:39.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā paṭhame yāme paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā;
mn36:39.1.eng: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.

mn36:39.2.pli: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
mn36:39.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

mn36:39.3.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:39.3.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:40.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṃ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
mn36:40.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.

mn36:40.2.pli: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passāmi cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāmi …pe…
mn36:40.2.eng: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings pass on according to their deeds.

mn36:41.1.pli: ayaṃ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā majjhime yāme dutiyā vijjā adhigatā;
mn36:41.1.eng: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.

mn36:41.2.pli: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
mn36:41.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

mn36:41.3.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:41.3.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:42.1.pli: So evaṃ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṃ khayañāṇāya cittaṃ abhininnāmesiṃ.
mn36:42.1.eng: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

mn36:42.2.pli: So ‘idaṃ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ.
mn36:42.2.eng: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

mn36:42.3.pli: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ, ‘ayaṃ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ.
mn36:42.3.eng: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’

mn36:43.1.pli: Tassa me evaṃ jānato evaṃ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, bhavāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha, avijjāsavāpi cittaṃ vimuccittha.
mn36:43.1.eng: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

mn36:43.2.eng: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.

mn36:43.3.pli: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā’ti abbhaññāsiṃ.
mn36:43.3.eng: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’

mn36:44.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho me, aggivessana, rattiyā pacchime yāme tatiyā vijjā adhigatā;
mn36:44.1.eng: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.

mn36:44.2.pli: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno; yathā taṃ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
mn36:44.2.eng: Ignorance was banished and knowledge arose; darkness was banished and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.

mn36:44.3.pli: Evarūpāpi kho me, aggivessana, uppannā sukhā vedanā cittaṃ na pariyādāya tiṭṭhati.
mn36:44.3.eng: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.

mn36:45.1.pli: Abhijānāmi kho panāhaṃ, aggivessana, anekasatāya parisāya dhammaṃ desetā.
mn36:45.1.eng: Aggivessana, I recall teaching the Dhamma to an assembly of many hundreds,
mn36:45.1.comm: This passage is unique and its purpose here unclear,

mn36:45.3.eng: that I was teaching the Dhamma especially for them.

mn36:45.4.pli: Na kho panetaṃ, aggivessana, evaṃ daṭṭhabbaṃ;
mn36:45.4.eng: But it should not be seen like this.

mn36:45.5.pli: yāvadeva viññāpanatthāya tathāgato paresaṃ dhammaṃ deseti.
mn36:45.5.eng: The Realized One teaches others only so that they can understand.

mn36:45.6.pli: So kho ahaṃ, aggivessana, tassāyeva kathāya pariyosāne, tasmiṃyeva purimasmiṃ samādhinimitte ajjhattameva cittaṃ saṇṭhapemi sannisādemi ekodiṃ karomi samādahāmi, yena sudaṃ niccakappaṃ viharāmī”ti.
mn36:45.6.eng: When that talk was finished, I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind in samādhi internally, using the same meditation subject as a basis of immersion that I used before, which I regularly use to meditate.”
mn36:45.6.comm: Here samādhinimitta as usual means the subject of meditation, probably the breath. | Niccakappa (“continuously”) occurs only here and at MN 144:11.2 = SN 35.87:11.2 where it also used in the sense of “regular subject of contemplation”.

mn36:45.7.pli: “Okappaniyametaṃ bhoto gotamassa yathā taṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn36:45.7.eng: “I’d believe that of the worthy Gotama, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
mn36:45.7.comm: Saccaka is not saying that the Buddha is enlightened, merely he is like one who is enlightened (yathā taṁ arahato).

mn36:45.8.pli: Abhijānāti kho pana bhavaṃ gotamo divā supitā”ti?
mn36:45.8.eng: But do you ever recall sleeping during the day?”
mn36:45.8.comm: Saccaka reveals his bad faith; he is more interested in trapping the Buddha than in learning.

mn36:46.1.pli: “Abhijānāmahaṃ, aggivessana, gimhānaṃ pacchime māse pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto catugguṇaṃ saṅghāṭiṃ paññapetvā dakkhiṇena passena sato sampajāno niddaṃ okkamitā”ti.
mn36:46.1.eng: “I do recall that in the last month of the summer, I have spread out my outer robe folded in four and lain down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.”

mn36:46.2.pli: “Etaṃ kho, bho gotama, eke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammohavihārasmiṃ vadantī”ti?
mn36:46.2.eng: “Some ascetics and brahmins call that a deluded abiding.”
mn36:46.2.comm: He deflects by pointing to others, as he also did at MN 35:11.4.

mn36:46.3.pli: “Na kho, aggivessana, ettāvatā sammūḷho vā hoti asammūḷho vā.
mn36:46.3.eng: “That’s not how to define whether someone is deluded or not.

mn36:46.4.pli: Api ca, aggivessana, yathā sammūḷho ca hoti asammūḷho ca,
mn36:46.4.eng: But as to how to define whether someone is deluded or not,

mn36:46.5.pli: taṃ suṇāhi, sādhukaṃ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
mn36:46.5.eng: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

mn36:46.6.pli: “Evaṃ, bho”ti kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato paccassosi.

mn36:47.1.pli: “Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā appahīnā, tamahaṃ ‘sammūḷho’ti vadāmi.
mn36:47.1.eng: “Anyone who has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death is deluded, I say.

mn36:47.2.eng: For it’s not giving up the defilements that makes you deluded.

mn36:47.3.pli: Yassa kassaci, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā, tamahaṃ ‘asammūḷho’ti vadāmi.
mn36:47.3.eng: Anyone who has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is not deluded, I say.

mn36:47.4.eng: For it’s giving up the defilements that makes you not deluded.

mn36:47.5.pli: Tathāgatassa kho, aggivessana, ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā.
mn36:47.5.eng: The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.

mn36:47.6.pli: Seyyathāpi, aggivessana, tālo matthakacchinno abhabbo puna virūḷhiyā;
mn36:47.6.eng: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,

mn36:47.7.pli: evameva kho, aggivessana, tathāgatassa ye āsavā saṅkilesikā ponobbhavikā sadarā dukkhavipākā āyatiṃ jātijarāmaraṇiyā pahīnā ucchinnamūlā tālāvatthukatā anabhāvaṅkatā āyatiṃ anuppādadhammā”ti.
mn36:47.7.eng: in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.”

mn36:48.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
mn36:48.1.eng: When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him,

mn36:48.3.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ bhoto gotamassa evaṃ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn36:48.3.eng: How when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!

mn36:48.4.pli: Abhijānāmahaṃ, bho gotama, pūraṇaṃ kassapaṃ vādena vādaṃ samārabhitā.
mn36:48.4.eng: I recall taking on Pūraṇa Kassapa in debate.

mn36:48.5.pli: Sopi mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddho aññenaññaṃ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
mn36:48.5.eng: He dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

mn36:48.6.pli: Bhoto pana gotamassa evaṃ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn36:48.6.eng: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn36:48.7.eng: I recall taking on the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla,

mn36:48.11.eng: and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan in debate.
mn36:48.11.comm: This shows that despite his Jain parentage, and despite his citation of Ājīvakas above, Saccaka was no adherent of these philosophies. It seems that he was a contrarian at heart.

mn36:48.12.pli: Sopi mayā vādena vādaṃ samāraddho aññenaññaṃ paṭicari, bahiddhā kathaṃ apanāmesi, kopañca dosañca appaccayañca pātvākāsi.
mn36:48.12.eng: They all dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.

mn36:48.13.pli: Bhoto pana gotamassa evaṃ āsajja āsajja vuccamānassa, upanītehi vacanappathehi samudācariyamānassa, chavivaṇṇo ceva pariyodāyati, mukhavaṇṇo ca vippasīdati, yathā taṃ arahato sammāsambuddhassa.
mn36:48.13.eng: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.

mn36:48.14.pli: Handa ca dāni mayaṃ, bho gotama, gacchāma.
mn36:48.14.eng: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.

mn36:48.15.eng: I have many duties, and much to do.”

mn36:48.17.pli: Atha kho saccako nigaṇṭhaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmīti.
mn36:48.17.eng: Then Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.
